Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships for Success in Computational Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at The College of New Jersey (TCNJ) improves mentoring and student support structures within the Departments of Computer Science, and Mathematics and Statistics. Dissemination of these results both within TCNJ and in the respective disciplines is leading to improved advising and mentoring practices by other departments and institutions.

This project forms the basis of a sustainable initiative to recruit, retain and graduate more students in computer science and mathematics at TCNJ. All students in the program engage in research, belong to a learning community, and are focused on computational science. These experiences form a common theme for the students in the program. Students are organized into project teams that work on research problems as part of their coursework from the start of their college career. The projects are structured to create a sustainable learning community that improves students' self-efficacy. The project provides significant advising, mentoring, and tutoring services that supplement those already provided by the college. The project funds approximately 27 scholarships per year for computer science and mathematics students at TCNJ.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Project "Scholarships for Success in Computational Science" (Award #1356235) provided scholarships and mentoring support to economically disadvantaged computer science and mathematics majors. The project's goal was to increase the number of graduates in computer science and mathematics from economically challenged backgrounds, with a focus on students from traditionally underrepresented groups (including women) in these fields, by improving the retention and graduation rates for these students. 

The program accomplished its goals. As of Summer 2019, 86% (24 of 28) of the students had either graduated in four years, or were on track to graduate in four years, having earned a bachelor's degree in mathematics or computer science. Including students who left the program for another major, 94% of the students (30 out of 32) graduated in four years or were on track to graduate in four years; 97% (31 out of 32), graduated on schedule after being accepted into the program; and 100% (32 out of 32) graduated either in five years, were on track to graduate in five years (1 student), or graduated on schedule (1 student) after being accepted into the program. By comparison, across all majors, 75% of the college's students graduate after four years, and 87% graduate after six years. Significantly, the improved graduation rate in the program was achieved despite the scholarship students having entered college with slightly lower levels of preparation when compared to other science majors. It is likely that two students would not have graduated without the mentoring and financial support provided by the program. 

The program also increased the success of students pursuing careers in computer science, mathematics, and statistics.  All of the students in the program who have graduated to date have completed school with a good job offer, acceptance into a graduate program, or a plan for further graduate study after taking a gap year.  The research experiences that students participated in led to stronger job offers than might otherwise be expected. Also, the program noticeably increased the number of mathematics students who pursued further studies in mathematics and statistics.  Seven of the fourteen mathematics majors in the program (50%) have pursued, or are in the process of pursuing, graduate studies in mathematics or statistics. In comparison, approximately 15% of the general mathematics population at the college pursues graduate study in these areas. 

 

The project provided extensive mentoring and research opportunities for the students. Students were engaged in undergraduate research projects in various areas of computational science beginning early in their college careers.  Students worked closely with their faculty research advisors for several semesters, and were provided more research opportunities than would have otherwise been available. Students also regularly participated in program activities that provided professional and career development opportunities.  In the final evaluation, program participants reported that the following activities were impactful in increasing student engagement in the disciplines of mathematics and computer science: (i) their early exposure to research experiences; (ii) their research projects; (iii) mentoring; and (iv) community-builiding program activities. The high retention and graduation rates of the students provides evidence for the project's intellectual merit that students benefit from engaging in research projects early in their college career. 

 

The project has had a broad impact by improving the professional development, mentoring, and student support for not just the supported scholarship students, but all mathematics and computer science students at the college.  The project involved students in research earlier in their college career than was traditional, and also involved students, with relatively weaker backgrounds than previous research students, in research projects. In both cases, positive benefits for students were documented, and have led to structural changes in the departments to increase research opportunities for a wider pool of students. The benefits of many of the program's community building activities have also resulted in their adoption for the department's overall student community.
